Program Name: Health Information Management
Code: C139
Credential: Ontario College Diploma
Duration: 2 years (4 semesters)
Starting Months: September
Domestic Tuition: $3,704.00 *
International Tuition: $17,435.00 **
Location: Waterfront Campus
Experiential Learning: Field education in semesters 3 and 4
Program Availability:
- Fall 2023: Closed for domestic students, closed for international students
- Winter 2024: Not Available for domestic students, Not Available for international students
- Spring 2024: Not Available for domestic students, Not Available for international students
Accreditation: Canadian Health Information Management Association (CHIMA)
*Domestic tuition fee is subject to change. **International tuition fee is subject to change and includes additional fees not applicable to domestic students.
question:
Program Description:
The Health Information Management (HIM) program at Seneca College is a 2-year Ontario College Diploma program, which provides students with the knowledge and skills required to manage health information in various healthcare settings. Students will learn about data management, information systems, privacy laws, and healthcare regulations, among other topics. The program includes both theoretical and practical components, with a strong emphasis on hands-on learning through laboratory sessions and field education placements in semesters 3 and 4.

Program Structure:
The HIM program consists of 12 full-time courses, delivered over four semesters. Students will attend classes at the Waterfront Campus in Toronto. The program includes both theoretical and practical components, with a strong emphasis on hands-on learning through laboratory sessions and field education placements in semesters 3 and 4.

Admission Requirements:
To be eligible for admission to the HIM program, applicants must meet the following requirements:

1. Ontario Secondary School Diploma (OSSD) or equivalent, with a minimum of six 12-unit Grade 12 C or U courses, including English 12C or U and Math 11M or U.
2. Achieve a minimum score of 75% in the CHIMA Health Information Management Admission Assessment.
3. Provide proof of immunization.

Program Delivery:
The HIM program is delivered in a full-time, on-campus format, with classes scheduled Monday to Friday. Students are required to attend classes and participate in laboratory sessions, simulations, and field education placements throughout the academic year. The program includes both theoretical and practical components, with a strong emphasis on hands-on learning.

Experiential Learning:
The HIM program includes two semesters of field education placements, which provide students with valuable work experience in healthcare settings. Students will apply the knowledge and skills they have learned in the classroom to real-world situations under the supervision of experienced professionals. The placements offer students an opportunity to gain practical experience in a variety of healthcare settings and develop essential professional competencies.

Accreditation:
The Health Information Management program at Seneca College is accredited by the Canadian Health Information Management Association (CHIMA). Graduates of the program are eligible for membership with CHIMA and can pursue national certification as a Registered Health Information Administrator (RHIA) or a Certified Health Records Analyst (CRHA), depending on their chosen career path.

Career Opportunities:
Graduates of the HIM program may find employment opportunities in various healthcare settings, including hospitals, long-term care facilities, clinics, and government agencies. Some potential job titles include Health Information Manager, Health Records Administrator, Data Analyst, Privacy Officer, and Health Information Technician. Additionally, graduates with an HIM diploma can continue their education to pursue a Bachelor's or Master's degree in Health Information Management or related fields.

Additional Fees:
There are additional fees associated with the HIM program, including textbooks, lab supplies, and field education placement fees. Students should consult the Seneca College website for up-to-date information on these costs.

Further Information:
For more detailed information about the Health Information Management program at Seneca College, including application procedures, tuition fees, course descriptions, and program requirements, please visit the Seneca College website or contact the Program Coordinator directly.

Note: This document is intended to provide an overview of the HIM program at Seneca College and is subject to change without notice. Students are encouraged to consult the official Seneca College calendar for the most accurate and up-to-date information on the program.?

context:
The Canadian Health Information Management Association (CHIMA) offers a certification program for Health Information Management practitioners. The curriculum covers various topics including biomedical sciences, health informatics, health record systems, medical classification systems and coding, data collection, statistical analysis and presentation, health-care legislation, and more.

Graduates of the program are eligible to write the Canadian Health Information Management Association national certification examination. The program requires students to bring their own laptop computer during the duration of the program.

Field placement is integrated throughout the second year of the program, with students visiting partner offices every Friday and completing a project related to health data during a three-week block placement. Field experiences can be conducted at various sites such as health-care facilities, Ontario Ministry of Health and Long-Term Care, health-related insurance companies, Ontario Hospital Association, and community care access centres. Some clinical or work placement partners may require students to show proof of full vaccination against COVID-19.

Career opportunities for Health Information Management graduates exist within the public and private sectors including acute care hospitals.
question:
Title: Health Information Management (HIM) Program at Seneca College: Overview, Curriculum, Field Placement, Certification, and Career Opportunities

Introduction:
Health Information Management (HIM) is a crucial aspect of the healthcare industry, dealing with the collection, analysis, protection, and communication of patient health information. The HIM program at Seneca College in Toronto, Ontario, Canada, provides students with the knowledge and skills necessary to excel in this field. In this article, we will explore the overview, curriculum, field placement, certification, and career opportunities for graduates of the Seneca College HIM program.

Overview:
The HIM program at Seneca College is a two-year diploma program designed to prepare students for careers in various health information management roles. The curriculum covers topics including health data systems, medical terminology, health record administration, statistical analysis, and health information technology. Students will also gain hands-on experience through field placements and internships.

Curriculum:
The Seneca College HIM program consists of the following courses:
1. Anatomy & Physiology for Health Professionals
2. Medical Terminology I & II
3. Health Records Administration I, II, & III
4. Data Collection and Management in Health Information Systems
5. Legal and Ethical Issues in Health Care
6. Health Informatics I & II
7. Health Information Technology
8. Health Statistical Analysis and Presentation
9. Research Methods for Health Professionals
10. Management of Health Information Systems
11. Field Placement I, II, & III

Field Placement:
Seneca College's HIM program includes a comprehensive field placement component. Students will participate in three distinct placements throughout their second year. The field experiences can be conducted at various sites such as health-care facilities, Ontario Ministry of Health and Long-Term Care, health-related insurance companies, Ontario Hospital Association, and community care access centres. Some clinical or work placement partners may require students to show proof of full vaccination against COVID-19.

Certification:
Graduates of the Seneca College HIM program are eligible to write the Canadian Health Information Management Association (CHIMA) national certification examination. CHIMA is the leading professional association for Health Information Management practitioners in Canada. The certification process ensures that graduates have met the required educational standards and possess the essential skills and knowledge necessary for a successful career in HIM.

Career Opportunities:
The HIM field offers numerous opportunities for career growth within the public and private sectors. Some potential career paths include:
1. Health Information Technician/Specialist
2. Health Records Clerk/Coordinator
3. Health Data Analyst
4. Health Information Systems Manager
5. Health Information Security Officer
6. Clinical Documentation Improvement Specialist
7. Health Care Compliance Officer
8. Medical Coding and Billing Specialist
9. Health Information Privacy Officer

Conclusion:
The HIM program at Seneca College offers students a comprehensive educational experience, providing them with the necessary skills and knowledge to excel in this dynamic field. With its strong curriculum, hands-on field placements, CHIMA certification preparation, and diverse career opportunities, the Seneca College HIM program is an excellent choice for those seeking a rewarding career in health information management.?

context:
Graduates of the Health Information Management program have employment opportunities in various sectors including acute care hospitals, primary health-care teams, ambulatory care facilities, workplace health and safety boards, health record consulting firms, Canadian Institute of Health Information, specialized hospitals, community care centres, Ministries of Health, computer companies, research centres, and insurance companies.

Graduates with certification from the Canadian Health Information Management Association can apply to Toronto Metropolitan University (formerly Ryerson University) for a Bachelor of Health Administration (BHA). They may also apply to Conestoga College for a Bachelor of Applied Health Information Science (BA HIS) degree and become eligible for the two-year BA HIS bridging program.

Courses required for the Health Information Management program in Semester 1 include Anatomy and Physiology, Pathophysiology I: Microbiology, Health Information Management I, Medical Terminology I, Health Care Law, Fundamental Mathematics for Health Information Management, Introduction to College Communication or Communicating Across Contexts.

In Semester 2, students take courses like Anatomy and Physiology/Genetics, Pathophysiology II, Health Information Management II, Medical Terminology II, Quantitative Methods and Hospital Statistics, Excel Applications, Transition to Employment.

The third semester includes courses such as Health Information Coding Classification I, Health Information Management Field Education I, Privacy and Release of Information, Inferential Statistics and Research Methods, and Excel II.

In the fourth semester, students study Health Information Systems, Health Data Management, Health Information Management Field Education II, Health Information Coding Classification II, and Epidemiology. They also take General Education electives.
question:
The Health Information Management (HIM) program at Conestoga College is designed to provide students with the knowledge and skills required to manage and protect the privacy of health information in various healthcare settings. Graduates of this program can find employment opportunities in hospitals, clinics, long-term care facilities, government agencies, insurance companies, and other healthcare organizations.

The HIM program is a two-year Ontario College Diploma program that consists of four semesters. In the first semester, students take courses like Anatomy and Physiology, Pathophysiology I: Microbiology, Health Information Management I, Medical Terminology I, Health Care Law, Fundamental Mathematics for Health Information Management, and Introduction to College Communication or Communicating Across Contexts.

In the second semester, students take courses like Anatomy and Physiology/Genetics, Pathophysiology II, Health Information Management II, Medical Terminology II, Quantitative Methods and Hospital Statistics, Excel Applications, and Transition to Employment.

The third semester includes courses such as Health Information Coding Classification I, Health Information Management Field Education I, Privacy and Release of Information, Inferential Statistics and Research Methods, and Excel II.

In the fourth semester, students study Health Information Systems, Health Data Management, Health Information Management Field Education II, Health Information Coding Classification II, and Epidemiology. They also take General Education electives.

Graduates with certification from the Canadian Health Information Management Association can apply to Toronto Metropolitan University (formerly Ryerson University) for a Bachelor of Health Administration (BHA). They may also apply to Conestoga College for a Bachelor of Applied Health Information Science (BA HIS) degree and become eligible for the two-year BA HIS bridging program.

The Health Information Management program provides students with a strong foundation in various areas of health information management, including health information coding and classification systems, health information privacy and security, health data management, health information technology, and health information systems analysis. Students will also develop practical skills through field education placements in healthcare organizations. Upon completion of the program, graduates will be eligible to write the national certification exam offered by the Canadian College of Health Information Management.?

context:
The text provides information about a Health Information Coding Classification II program offered by the college with the EPID code 2001. Students may be required to take COMM 1000 before progressing to COMM 2000. The program aims to help graduates keep current with health care and health information management issues, assess personal health information for accuracy, apply codes and standards to relevant health information, comply with legal and ethical standards, contribute to the development of health information management practices, and use current technologies to support health information management.

The tuition information provided is for domestic students only. No specific fee or cost details are mentioned in the text. The Assessment Centre can be visited for more information regarding COMM 1000 requirement.

Program Learning Outcomes:
1. Keep current with relevant local, national and global health care and health information management issues, trends, technologies and standards.
2. Assess personal health information from individual client visits for accuracy, completeness and consistency.
3. Apply current, accurate codes and standards to relevant personal health information.
4. Comply with legal obligations and professional, ethical, and organizational standards related to privacy, security and confidentiality in accessing, retaining, storing, and disposing of personal health information.
5. Contribute to the development, implementation, and evaluation of health information management practices, policies, and processes.
6. Participate in maintaining the completeness, accuracy, consistency, timeliness, and integrity of health information throughout its lifecycle.
7. Use knowledge of systems interoperability standards, database architecture, software versioning, classification and terminology mapping, data collection requirements, legal obligations, and the health information management lifecycle to support the procurement and implementation of health information management systems.
8. Retrieve and release personal health information in response to legitimate requests within specified deadlines.
9. Participate in retrieving, analyzing, and presenting relevant health information to stakeholders for organizational decision-making, epidemiological studies, and clinical research.
10. Work professionally, ethically, and collaboratively with stakeholders and as a member of the interdisciplinary healthcare team within a structured, regulated, and evolving system of healthcare to enhance the collection, distribution, use, security, and awareness of quality health information and its impact on client care.
11. Use current and emerging technologies to support the management, analysis, and presentation of health information.
question:
Title: Health Information Management Program (COMM 2001) at XYZ College

The XYZ College offers a Health Information Coding Classification II program under the EPID code 2001 for students interested in keeping up-to-date with health care and health information management issues. Students may need to take COMM 1000 before advancing to COMM 2000. The program aims to prepare graduates to assess personal health information for accuracy, apply codes and standards, comply with legal and ethical standards, contribute to the development of health information management practices, and use current technologies.

Tuition information is only available for domestic students. For more details regarding COMM 1000 prerequisite, please visit the Assessment Centre.

Learning Outcomes:
1. Stay informed about local, national, and global health care and health information management trends, issues, technologies, and standards.
2. Evaluate personal health information from individual client encounters for accuracy, completeness, and consistency.
3. Apply current codes and standards to relevant personal health information.
4. Adhere to legal obligations and professional, ethical, organizational standards regarding privacy, security, confidentiality in handling personal health information.
5. Contribute to the development, implementation, and evaluation of health information management practices, policies, and processes.
6. Ensure completeness, accuracy, consistency, timeliness, and integrity of health information throughout its lifecycle.
7. Understand various systems interoperability standards, database architecture, software versioning, classification and terminology mapping, data collection requirements, legal obligations, and the health information management lifecycle to support health information system procurement and implementation.
8. Retrieve and release personal health information in a timely manner to fulfill legitimate requests.
9. Analyze and present relevant health information to stakeholders for organizational decision-making, epidemiological studies, and clinical research.
10. Collaborate with stakeholders and healthcare team members within a structured system of healthcare to enhance the collection, distribution, use, security, and awareness of quality health information and its impact on client care.
11. Utilize current and emerging technologies to support the management, analysis, and presentation of health information.?

question:
Title: Bachelor of Science in Nursing (BSN) - Field Placement Requirements

The Bachelor of Science in Nursing (BSN) program at XYZ University has certain health and placement requirements for students. These requirements are essential to ensure the safety and wellbeing of patients, clients, and students during clinical placements.

1. Health Requirements:
Students must meet specific health requirements before starting their field placements. These requirements include having up-to-date immunizations, a negative tuberculosis (TB) test result within the past year, and being free from any communicable diseases. Students should consult with their campus Health Services office to ensure they meet these requirements.

2. Police Vulnerable Sector Check:
Students are required to obtain a Police Vulnerable Sector Check for field or clinical placements in the program. The Police Vulnerable Sector Check must be renewed annually and covers appropriateness for individuals working with vulnerable persons. The process typically takes two to three months but can take up to eight months. Students are responsible for paying the fees associated with these requirements and keeping the original copy of their Police Vulnerable Sector Check. International students should visit the International Admissions page for country-specific admission requirements. Students who cannot provide a "clear" check may not be able to start their placement and therefore may be unable to complete the program.

3. Pre-placement:
The text mentions a Pre-placement website, but no link is provided. We recommend that students visit the pre-placement portal regularly for important updates and information related to their clinical placements.

4. COVID-19 Vaccination:
Public health recommends that students be fully vaccinated against COVID-19 to complete the field placement component in the regularly scheduled time frame. This requirement may vary depending on the specific placement site's policies and local public health guidelines. Students should consult with their clinical placement sites regarding any COVID-19 vaccination requirements.

5. Application:
Domestic students should apply through the unspecified application method for clinical placements. International students should visit the International Admissions page for country-specific admission requirements.

For more information, please contact the School of Nursing at XYZ University.?

question:
Title: Apply to Health Programs at George Brown College

George Brown College offers various health programs for students who are interested in pursuing a career in the field. Domestic applicants should apply through Ontario Colleges, while international students can use the George Brown College Online Application System. For more information about applying and available programs, contact the School of Health Services Management at 416-415-5000, ext. 2367 or [hsmprograms@georgebrown.ca](mailto:hsmprograms@georgebrown.ca).

Programs offered include:
1. Health Informatics (Postgraduate)
2. Office Administration – Health Services
3. Practical Nursing (PN)
4. Health Information Management

Quote from Alumnus Xiyuan (Siuwin) Wang: "The value I gained from the Health Information Management program at George Brown College has been invaluable to my career."

Contact information for booking campus tours or info sessions and signing up to receive application resources is available on the George Brown College Contact Us page. Additional programs include:
1. Health Informatics (Postgraduate)
2. Office Administration – Health Services
3. Practical Nursing (PN)

You can also book a virtual meeting with international recruitment representatives or submit an inquiry for further information. To apply, follow the application methods provided according to your student status.?
